articles.headline: Prosecutors Say Ohtani’s Interpreter Stole $16 Million From Star
articles.snippet: The interpreter, Ippei Mizuhara, was charged with bank fraud, after prosecutors said he stole money to pay his gambling debts.
articles.abstract: The interpreter, Ippei Mizuhara, was charged with bank fraud, after prosecutors said he stole money to pay his gambling debts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors said on Thursday that Shohei Ohtani had been the victim of a “fraud on a massive scale,” releasing a detailed complaint that claimed Ippei Mizuhara, the baseball star’s former interpreter, exploited his access and the fact that Ohtani did not speak English to steal $16 million from him to feed his gambling addiction.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: NPR in Turmoil After It Is Accused of Liberal Bias
articles.snippet: An essay from an editor at the broadcaster has generated a firestorm of criticism about the network on social media, especially among conservatives.
articles.abstract: An essay from an editor at the broadcaster has generated a firestorm of criticism about the network on social media, especially among conservatives.
articles.lead_paragraph: NPR is facing both internal tumult and a fusillade of attacks by prominent conservatives this week after a senior editor publicly claimed the broadcaster had allowed liberal bias to affect its coverage, risking its trust with audiences.
articles.byline: By Benjamin Mullin and Katie Robertson

articles.headline: Europe’s A.I. ‘Champion’ Sets Sights on Tech Giants in U.S.
articles.snippet: Mistral, a French start-up considered a promising challenger to OpenAI and Google, is getting support from European leaders who want to protect the region’s culture and politics.
articles.abstract: Mistral, a French start-up considered a promising challenger to OpenAI and Google, is getting support from European leaders who want to protect the region’s culture and politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: Arthur Mensch, tall and lean with a flop of unkempt hair, arrived for a speech last month at a sprawling tech hub in Paris wearing jeans and carrying a bicycle helmet. He had an unassuming look for a person European officials are counting on to help propel the region into a high-stakes match with the United States and China over artificial intelligence.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman and Adam Satariano

articles.headline: How the War in Gaza Mobilized the American Left
articles.snippet: As the death toll in Gaza climbed, the pro-Palestinian movement grew into a powerful, if disjointed, political force in the United States. Democrats are feeling the pressure.
articles.abstract: As the death toll in Gaza climbed, the pro-Palestinian movement grew into a powerful, if disjointed, political force in the United States. Democrats are feeling the pressure.
articles.lead_paragraph: Support for Palestinians, a cause once largely championed on college campuses and in communities with ties to the region, has transformed into a defining issue of the Democratic left, galvanizing a broad swath of groups into the most significant protest movement of the Biden era.
articles.byline: By Katie Glueck, Katie Benner and Sheera Frenkel

articles.headline: Ghost Kitchens Are Disappearing, Squeezed by Demand and Complaints
articles.snippet: Delivery-only operations boomed during the pandemic. Now Wendy’s, Kroger and mom-and-pop food businesses are rethinking their operations.
articles.abstract: Delivery-only operations boomed during the pandemic. Now Wendy’s, Kroger and mom-and-pop food businesses are rethinking their operations.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon, the kitchen inside a Denny’s in the Jackson Heights neighborhood of Queens was bustling.

articles.headline: With State Bans on D.E.I., Some Universities Find a Workaround: Rebranding
articles.snippet: Welcome to the new “Office of Access and Engagement.” Schools are renaming departments and job titles to try to preserve diversity programs.
articles.abstract: Welcome to the new “Office of Access and Engagement.” Schools are renaming departments and job titles to try to preserve diversity programs.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the University of Tennessee, the campus D.E.I. program is now called the Division of Access and Engagement.

articles.headline: Where Kamala Harris Lives, a Little-Known History of Enslavement
articles.snippet: The vice president’s official residence is in a quiet Washington enclave once home to 34 enslaved people. Ms. Harris has sought to reconnect the property to its Black heritage.
articles.abstract: The vice president’s official residence is in a quiet Washington enclave once home to 34 enslaved people. Ms. Harris has sought to reconnect the property to its Black heritage.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three years ago this month, Vice President Kamala Harris moved into her official residence in northwest Washington, a quiet 73-acre enclave where the U.S. Navy keeps an observatory as well as the nation’s master clock. Early in her stay she saw evidence of digging near her house, and after asking around, learned that an archaeological team had recently found part of a foundation of an Italianate villa, known as North View, that had been there more than a century and a half before.

articles.headline: War or No War, Ukrainians Aren’t Giving Up Their Coffee
articles.snippet: Coffee shops and kiosks are everywhere in Ukraine’s capital, their popularity both an act of wartime defiance and a symbol of closer ties to the rest of Europe.
articles.abstract: Coffee shops and kiosks are everywhere in Ukraine’s capital, their popularity both an act of wartime defiance and a symbol of closer ties to the rest of Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Russian tanks first rolled into Ukraine more than two years ago, Artem Vradii was sure his business was bound to suffer.
articles.byline: By Constant Méheut, Daria Mitiuk and Brendan Hoffman

articles.headline: Immigrants in Maine Are Filling a Labor Gap. It May Be a Prelude for the U.S.
articles.snippet: A wave of rapid immigration is taxing local resources around the country and drawing political ire. But it might leave America’s economy better off.
articles.abstract: A wave of rapid immigration is taxing local resources around the country and drawing political ire. But it might leave America’s economy better off.
articles.lead_paragraph: Maine has a lot of lobsters. It also has a lot of older people, ones who are less and less willing and able to catch, clean and sell the crustaceans that make up a $1 billion industry for the state. Companies are turning to foreign-born workers to bridge the divide.

articles.headline: Dimon Warns of ‘Unsettling’ Pressures That Could Weigh on JPMorgan Earnings
articles.snippet: Warnings from the chief executive of the nation’s largest bank have been consistently at odds with heady financial markets.
articles.abstract: Warnings from the chief executive of the nation’s largest bank have been consistently at odds with heady financial markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, on Friday warned of an “unsettling” global landscape, highlighting a cascade of pressures, including war, rising geopolitical tensions and inflation, that threaten the economy and could weigh on the performance of the nation’s largest bank.
